title: Where can I find GRUB 2 (v1.98) already compiled ?

forumNotes.author: DSpider
forumNotes.content:
Title pretty much sums it up.  

Can someone please compile *grub-1.98.tar.gz* from [ftp://alpha.gnu.org/gnu/grub/](ftp://alpha.gnu.org/gnu/grub/ "External link") ?  

I don't have access to a Linux powered computer. Perhaps with a Live CD version ?

forumNotes.author: dog
forumNotes.content:
What are you planning to boot with it, if not linux?  
Grub2 is not grub4dos.

forumNotes.author: DSpider
forumNotes.content:
The USB stick will be used for installing Arch Linux, WinXP and running Parted Magic and a few other utilities. I would change it to ext2 but GRUB 0.4.5a doesn't want to boot it properly. Perhaps it's just a bug in Arch.  

menuentry "Arch" {  
loopback loop /iso/archlinux-2009.08-netinstall-x86_64.iso  
set root=loop  
linux /boot/vmlinuz26 lang=en locale=en_US.UTF-8 archisolabel=ARCHISO_OHD8FOH5 ramdisk_size=75%  
initrd /boot/archiso_pata.img  
}

forumNotes.author: DSpider
forumNotes.content: I thought 1.98 was final (ie. no "beta" anywhere).

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> I thought 1.98 was final (ie. no "beta" anywhere). My bad. :smile: I thought that [ftp://alpha.gnu.org/](ftp://alpha.gnu.org/ "External link") meant "alpha" only.
Additionally the good ubuntu guys have removed the precompiled rescue builds from 1.98 : grub-rescue-pc_1.98-1ubuntu2_i386.deb I guess that you can get away with it if you get the "plain" [https://launchpad.ne...c/1.98-1ubuntu2](https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/lucid/i386/grub-pc/1.98-1ubuntu2 "External link") And use these instructions under any LiveCD: [http://grub.enbug.org/TestingOnX86](http://grub.enbug.org/TestingOnX86 "External link") > You can generate core.img with grub-install (GRUB 2) by following way: > > grub-install --grub-setup=/bin/true /dev/sda > > Change /dev/sda to match your device. > > Note: This will not install GRUB 2 (core.img) to your MBR. Instead it executes /bin/true for installation which does not do the actual installation. It will prepare core.img and copy necessary files to /boot/grub folder. I woud like to use this occasion to publicly state how **Wonko the Sane** personally thinks that the good grub2 developers and the very good ubuntu (you can substitute with ANY other Linux distro here) guys have succeeded in finding the most unfriendly way to distribute/install their app ever seen, additionally lacking of ANY useful documentation and making things uneedingly overcomplex for anyone wishing to try it. :smile:

:smile: Wonko

> >
> > :smile: > Wonko True... the GNU people are working hard on GRUB2 . The documentation is lagging, but it will eventually catch up. It's not really an app, it's more of a boot loader. The easiest way to install it to a flash drive or even a hard drive is to boot the latest Ubuntu LiveCD and use the grub-install command. However, On my Linux Mint partition, I installed the grub-common and the grub-pc (i386) packages for version 1.98 from the Debian ftp and it works great. Now I am set up to install this version on to any flash drive if needed. I have a lot of GRUB2 bookmarks which I have read, and for now it seems to fill in the gaps until the official docs are finished: Official Intro: [http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/](http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/ "External link") Official (incomplete) Manual: [http://grub.enbug.org/Manual](http://grub.enbug.org/Manual "External link") Commands: [http://grub.enbug.org/CommandList](http://grub.enbug.org/CommandList "External link") (Good Info) How it is on Ubuntu: [https://help.ubuntu....community/Grub2](https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Grub2 "External link") Good example how to make a multi-iso boot flash drive, with good grub-install example: [http://www.panticz.de/MultiBootUSB](http://www.panticz.de/MultiBootUSB "External link") Good intro on editing the grub.cfg from Linux, although not needed on flash drive (see above): [http://www.dedoimedo...ers/grub-2.html](http://www.dedoimedo.com/computers/grub-2.html "External link") Once on an Ubuntu LiveCD, using the man pages can help derive more info (e.g. grub-install): > GRUB-INSTALL(8) System Administration Utilities GRUB-INSTALL(8) > >
> >
> > NAME > grub-install - manual page for grub-install (GNU GRUB > 1.98\~20100128-1.2) > > SYNOPSIS > grub-install \[OPTION\] install_device > > DESCRIPTION > Install GRUB on your drive. > > -h, --help > print this message and exit > > -v, --version > print the version information and exit > > --modules=MODULES > pre-load specified modules MODULES > > --root-directory=DIR > install GRUB images under the directory DIR instead of the root > directory > > --grub-setup=FILE > use FILE as grub-setup > > --grub-mkimage=FILE > use FILE as grub-mkimage > > --grub-mkdevicemap=FILE use FILE as grub-mkdevicemap > > --grub-probe=FILE > use FILE as grub-probe > > --no-floppy > do not probe any floppy drive > > --recheck > probe a device map even if it already exists > > --force > install even if problems are detected > > --disk-module=MODULE > disk module to use > > INSTALL_DEVICE can be a GRUB device name or a system device filename. > > grub-install copies GRUB images into /boot/grub (or /grub on NetBSD and > OpenBSD), and uses grub-setup to install grub into the boot sector. > > If the --root-directory option is used, then grub-install will copy > images into the operating system installation rooted at that directory. > > REPORTING BUGS > Report bugs to \. > >
> >
> > FSF February 2010 GRUB-INSTALL(8) I hope this is useful... breaker EDIT: Here is the Debian FTP with the compiled packages: [http://ftp.debian.or...l/main/g/grub2/](http://ftp.debian.org/debian/pool/main/g/grub2/ "External link")
